ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

PRIME MINISTER'S DISCUSSION WITH BRITISH
AND UNITED STATES GOVERNMENTS
(Request for Statement)


    1. Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam asked the Prime Minister if he will report to the House on the discussions he has had with the British and United States governments on matters concerning and touching Singapore on his recent visits to the United Kingdom and the United States of America.

     The Prime Minister: Mr Speaker, Sir, Singapore's bilateral relations with both Britain and the United States are excellent and there were no bilateral political or economic issues that were contentious or required detailed discussion. Both visits were opportunities to renew contacts at the highest levels of the British and American governments, to strengthen existing ties, and to exchange views on issues of mutual concern.

    The state of the American economy was a major subject. The prolonged recession in the United States is being increasingly felt in Singapore and I registered our concern. The leaders in Washington want to tackle the problem at its roots, which is to cut down social security spending under the "entitlements" programme, which are indexed or linked to the consumer price index. However, my impression, gathered from talking to several leading members of the Senate and of the House of Representatives, was that in an election year, the

Column: 97

Congress could not contemplate legislating such welfare cuts.

    President Reagan's top aides were confident that there would be an economic recovery later in the year, and that social spending cuts would become possible after the mid-term Congressional elections. I was particularly encouraged by Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldridge's commitment to free trade and of his stand against protectionism.

    I brought abreast American and British leaders on developments in South-east Asia, in particular, the dangers arising from Vietnam's occupation of Cambodia. I explained the circumstances which finally led to the successful formation of the Coalition Government of Democratic Kampuchea to combine all patriotic Cambodians to oppose Vietnamese occupation. American and British leaders were aware of the implications for ASEAN of Vietnam's continuing occupation of Cambodia. Both governments will continue to support ASEAN's efforts to find a political solution by a Vietnamese withdrawal and the holding of a UN supervised elections under the terms of the UN resolution at the International Conference on Kampuchea (ICK) in July 1981, to allow the Cambodian people to freely elect their own government. I was also reassured by America's commitment to Thailand's security and America's obligations to Thailand under the Manila Pact.

    Much of the other reportable items of my discussions with individual leaders have already been reported immediately after the meetings, by the news agencies and by several Singapore newsmen who accompanied me.

PREMATURE SCHOOL LEAVERS
(Raising of literacy and basic skills)


    2. Mr Liew Kok Pun asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education (a) the number and percentage of persons by any convenient age groups between 6 and 14 years of age who are now not in schools or in any other educa-

Column: 98

tional institutions; and (b) whether there is any firm plan by the Ministry of Education and the Vocational and Industrial Training Board to introduce compulsory education or to require all premature school leavers to undergo some form of vocational-technical or work-related training, to ensure that entrants into the workforce have got a minimum level of literacy or basic skills to cope with a more advanced technological work environment in the 1980's.

     The Minister of State of Education (Dr Tay Eng Soon) (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, in answer to the first Part of the Member's question, I provide a Table (Cols. 199 - 200) obtained from the Department of Statistics from the Population Census of 1980. I would like to ask the Clerk of Parliament to distribute this Table to Members of the House.
Table - Non-Schooling Population (Cols. 199 - 200)


    [Copies handed in and distributed to hon. Members.]

    The Table gives the percentage of children at each age level from 5 to 14 who are not attending school or an educational institution of any kind. These figures need some explanation. Most of those at the age of 5 or 6 are either attending kindergarten or are in school. But, as to be expected, a percentage of them are not yet in any kindergarten or school. From age 7 onwards, the great majority, i.e. over 99%, are in school. Those who are not attending school at ages 12 to 14, as shown on the Table, are those who have dropped out of school, mainly at Primary 6, on failure of their PSLE or on being overaged.

    In answer to the second part of the Member's question, Sir, I appreciate and share the Member for Boon Teck's concern that all premature school leavers should undergo some form of vocational or work-related training before they join the employment market, This problem will become more acute as the effects of world recession begin to reach us. In any retrenchment resulting from recession, the first to go will be the unskilled workers. Although we do not yet have much retrenchment in Singapore, among the 1,652 workers who were retrenched during the second quarter of this year, 8 out of 10

Column: 99

were without skills. This underlines the importance of having a skill.

    My Ministry and VITB have carefully considered whether it is feasible to introduce legislation for compulsory education. Our conclusion is that at the present time it is not necessary nor desirable to legislate for compulsory education. I am aware that there are many countries which have compulsory education both in their academic as well as their vocational schools. This measure has, however, not necessarily ensured that all their children will leave school educated or skilled. In fact, it is well-known that compelling unwilling and unmotivated pupils to stay in school leads to increased problems of truancy, discipline and delinquency. In the United Kingdom, for example, special officers have to be employed to enforce compulsory schooling to make sure that truancy cases are followed up.

    Instead of legislating for compulsory education, my Ministry and VITB will try out an alternative approach based on automatic registration. Under automatic registration, all school leavers from the monolingual stream and all premature school leavers from Primary 6 and above will automatically be registered for vocational training at VITB. Although the final say will still rest with the parents, automatic registration should see many more premature school leavers joining VITB than at present.

    For the first batch of those leaving the monolingual stream at the end of 1984, VITB is preparing a special Pre-Vocational Training Course for them. This course will provide the pupils with project work to develop basic vocational skills. It will also include classes on language and numeracy skills, work attitude development and physical education. Monolingual pupils who go through Pre-Vocational Training can go on to Basic Engineering and NTC-3 trade courses at VITB.

    Those who join VITB after PSLE or from the secondary schools will go into the Basic Engineering Course which leads to NTC-3 and NTC-2 skill courses.

    At the moment details are being worked out between my Ministry and VITB for direct entry into the NTC-3, NTC-2, and ITC

Column: 100

courses for pupils who have completed their Certificate in Secondary Education (CSE) as well as those with some 'O' level passes. The details of these will be released by VITB in the near future.

    Automatic registration will not achieve a 100% transfer of premature school leavers from schools to VITB, but it should ensure that the majority will be placed in a course at the VITB.

    To make sure that the prospects of skill training are well understood by school leavers, VITB is working on publicity materials, including audio-visual presentations on vocational training. These materials will be specially directed at schools where there are pupils in the monolingual and extended streams in primary schools and at the normal stream in secondary schools.

    We are expanding VITB from its present enrolment of 11,000 to more than 24,000 by 1985. Many employers, especially those of high technology industries, prefer workers who have a skill to offer. This should motivate many of our school leavers to seek vocational training.

HINDU STUDIES IN ENGLISH


    3. Mr P. Selvadurai asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education why Hindu Studies, which will be one of the subjects offered under the Religious Knowledge Courses proposed for Secondary Ill and Secondary IV students, will be offered only in English and not in Tamil as well.

     Dr Tay Eng Soon (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am replying to this question on behalf of the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education.

    When Hindu Studies is made available as one of the Religious Knowledge subjects in 1984, it will be taught in English. At a later stage, if there is sufficient demand from students and parents, it can also be offered as an option in Tamil.

    Our records show that out of 4,330 Indian students in Secondary 3 and Secondary 4 in 1982, less than half or only 46% are taking Tamil as a second language. Most of the rest are taking Malay as

Column: 101

a second language, On the other hand, all Indian students study English. The teaching of Hindu Studies in English should therefore enable more Indian students, many of whom are not Tamil speaking, to take up the subject.

    The importance of English is well recognized. The use of English for teaching of Hindu Studies should help the students to improve their English. In contrast, the second language poses few problems for the majority of students and does not need as much encouragement as English. In the case of Tamil as a second language, 87.3% passed it at 'O' level in 1981 compared with 40% for English.

    As the Hindu Studies course will be a new and an untried one, the Hindu Advisory Board, with whom we are in close consultation, has agreed that the course should first be offered in English. They have further cautioned that the new syllabus as well as the textbooks should be thoroughly tested in the schools. Until the teething problems of the new textbooks are sorted out, the Hindu Advisory Board feels that it would be premature to offer the course as an option in Tamil.

    They have also pointed out that mainstream Hindu thought in India today is studied and taught in English at major Hindu centres of learning rather than in any of the Indian languages. Most of the great Indian scholar-thinkers who led the modern Hindu renaissance were men like R. Tagore, Aurobindo Gosh, M. K. Gandhi, S. Radhakrishnan and Swami Vivekananda. Their major works were in English. The study of Hindu Studies in English would give the students access to these great works.

    Finally, Tamil parents should not worry that their children will lose touch with the Tamil language by studying Hindu Studies in English, nor should they worry that their children will become unfamiliar with Hindu literature in the Tamil language. Tamil, as a second language which their children will study for 10 years from Primary 1 to Secondary 4, includes many passages and poems taken from the Hindu classics. Approximately 60% of the materials studied in the TL2 course consists of

Column: 102

moral education passages and religious poems taken from Hindu literature. Children who take TL2 are therefore well exposed to Tamil Hindu literature.

COLLEGE FOR PHYSICAL EDUCATION
(Establishment)


    4. Encik Abbas Abu Amin asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education when the proposed College for Physical Education will materialize, and how it will help to upgrade the general standard of physical fitness of our young population.

     Dr Tay Eng Soon (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, a feasibility study for a Physical Education College began early this year. The study has been completed and is now awaiting the comments and advice of an expert consultant who will be coming from West Germany in September. Depending on the outcome of the consultant's visit, it may be possible to start the PE College sometime next year or 1984 at the latest. It is envisaged that the College will take in 'O' and 'A' level students and award a Diploma in Physical Education after a three-year course.

    My Ministry has been concerned for some time about how to improve the standard of physical fitness of our pupils. We recognize that a well-run compulsory PE programme in our schools would be the way to improve physical fitness. To achieve this, we need to provide our schools with enough trained PE teachers. There is, however, an acute shortage of such teachers. At present, only 50 of our PE teachers have diplomas, certificates or degrees in PE while the rest have partial or no training.

    Over the next 10 years we will need at least 70 to 80 trained PE teachers each year for our secondary schools and junior colleges. The proposed PE College will not only train PE teachers for our schools but also PE instructors for the SAF, the Singapore Police Force, the Singapore Sports Council, People's Association and other organizations. We have neglected PE in our schools for far too long. The starting of the PE College and a PE programme in our schools should rectify this neglect.

PROHIBITION OF SMOKING IN RECREATION CENTRES


    5. Mr Yeo Choo Kok: To ask the Minister for the Environment whether his Ministry has been successful in enforcing the prohibition of smoking in cinema halls and lifts and if he will consider extending such prohibition to bowling alleys and other recreation centres.

     Mr Speaker: Mr Yeo Choo Kok.

     Mr Sia Kah Hui (Paya Lebar): Question No. 5, Sir.

     The Minister for the Environment (Mr Ong Pang Boon): Mr Speaker, Sir, very few people are found smoking in cinemas, buses and lifts nowadays. Generally, the people in Singapore have accepted and responded to the ban against smoking in such places.

    My Ministry will ban smoking in indoor amusement centres for electronic games, even though they will all be closed down next year. This is necessary as these places are very confined and often crowded with children and young adults and smoking in such places is therefore undesirable.

    Bowling alleys, however, are more spacious and less crowded and smoking in such places does not pose a serious threat to public health.

SINGAPORE POLICE FORCE
(Review by Japanese and British Study Teams)


    6. Mr Rohan bin Kamis asked the Minister for Home Affairs what is the status of the reports submitted by the Japanese and British Study Teams in their reviews of the Singapore Police Force in early 1982; whether the recommendations are acceptable; when these will be implemented, and how will the public be affected.

     The Minister for Home Affairs (Mr Chua Sian Chin): Mr Speaker, Sir, Members will recall that two years ago in this House, the Member for Punggol raised the issue of the building of new police stations. Other Members were also interested to know why there was a delay in the resiting of old police stations and the building of new

Column: 104

ones when there had been a shift of population concentrations to HDB housing estates. I had explained then that the Police could not proceed to build more police stations as there was a divergence of views between the Ministry of Finance and the Ministry of Home Affairs over the concept of police stations and the policing system. Although the Ministry of Home Affairs had proposed in 1976 to increase the police divisions to 10 with each having a Police Headquarters Station, it was not able to obtain approval for this. To break the impasse, it was decided to bring in foreign experts to study our policing system and to make recommendations.

    During the Budget debate this year, I disclosed to this House that a Japanese and a British team were studying our Police Force. The Japanese Study Team was invited to study the feasibility of introducing Koban type of policing system in Singapore with the object of improving police-community relations. The Japanese Study Team recommended that the Koban system could be introduced here, subject to modifications to suit local conditions. A network of 91 police posts was recommended with each constituency having at least one post to work closely with the CCCs, CCMCs and RCs. The larger constituencies would have more than one Police Post. This Police Post System would provide the police presence in housing estates.

    The British Study Team also came to the conclusion that a community based scheme of policing such as the Koban system is feasible and can be phased into our reorganized policing system. Recommendations were also made by the British Study Team for a new deployment strategy involving:-

    (i) the re-demarcation of police divisional boundaries;

    (ii) the addition of police stations;

    (iii) the upgrading of the communication system; and

    (iv) the increase in the establishment of police officers.

    The Government has accepted the recommendations of the two Study Teams. We are therefore pressing ahead with the implementation of the recom-

Column: 105

mendations. The British Study Team had recommended that there be 10 Police Headquarters Stations by 1985, 13 by 1991 and 15 beyond 1991. Preparation work has already begun on six new police stations. They are for the proposed two new police divisions and four replacements of existing old stations. The six stations are as follows:-

    (i) Woodlands (for new division)

    (ii) Clementi (for new division)

    (iii) Bedok (replacement for Joo Chiat)

    (iv) Ang Mo Kio (replacement for Paya Lebar)

    (v) Cantonment (replacement for Central)

    (vi) Geylang (replacement for Beach Road)

    The boundaries of our police divisions will be re-drawn to be contiguous with constituency boundaries. No longer will Members of Parliament have to deal with two or three OCs as at present because their constituencies cut across police divisional boundaries.

    Before implementing our new Neighbourhood Police Post System modelled on the Koban system, we will first carry out an evaluation phase. This is to evaluate operational procedures and gauge public acceptance of the system. The evaluation phase will be carried out in one police division in October next year. 'B' Division has been chosen for this purpose and architects are already working on plans for nine police posts, one in each of the constituencies in the division except Boon Teck which will have two posts. They will be built mainly in HDB void decks. The evaluation phase will be one year.

    The Neighbourhood Police Post System requires a radical change of attitudes of our Police officers to be more community-oriented. An orientation programme for the serving officers has begun. New police recruits will not only be trained on neighbourhood policing methods, but will also be inculcated with the spirit of good police-community relations. A team of Japanese experts has been in Singapore for the last two months to conduct training

Column: 106

courses for our instructors at our Police Academy. They are imparting their personal experiences and knowledge of the Koban System to our officers. Japanese experts will also be helping us in the preparation of the evaluation phase as well as to evaluate its results.

    An elaborate programme is being drawn up to brief community leaders and grassroots organizations on the new Neighbourhood Police Post System. The discussion with the community leaders will centre on the workings of the system, how they could be involved in it so as to maximize the benefits to the community. Initially this will be confined to the constituencies under the evaluation phase. Once the system is ready for full implementation, the other constituencies will be involved.

    With the implementation of this new Policing System, policing in Singapore will take on a new dimension by being an integral part of the life of the neighbourhood. We should then be able to drastically reduce our crime rate in all our neighbourhoods.

12-HOUR SHIFT SYSTEM
(Implementation)


    7. Mr Goh Chee Wee asked the Minister for Communications and Minister for Labour (a) how many companies in Singapore have implemented the 12-hour shift system; and (b) if the Ministry of Labour has examined the merits and demerits of such a system and whether or not the health and safety of workers have been taken into consideration.

     The Minister of State for Labour (Dr Wong Kwei Cheong) (for the Minister for Communications and Minister for Labour): Mr Speaker, Sir, according to information available to the Ministry of Labour, five companies have implemented the 12-hour shift system in certain sections of their companies. Another five organizations have indicated interest in this shift system.

    The advantages of the 12-hour shift system are:

    (i) It may help to overcome workers' reluctance to work on the late night shift and reduce our dependence on foreign workers.

Column: 107



    (ii) The system saves transport costs for the workers and enable them to enjoy more rest days.

    (iii) It optimizes the use of expensive plant and machinery.

    The disadvantages are:

    (i) It may affect the social activities of workers during the days they work.

    (ii) Employees are more susceptible to fatigue if the work requires strenuous physical effort and high concentration. Hence the 12-hour shift may not be suitable for such industries.

    According to the experience of the five companies which operated this system, they have not reported any significant increase in the number of industrial accidents. There is also no indication that their workers' health is affected in any significant way except for fatigue in the initial period.

     Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I ask the Minister of State whether, in implementing this 12-hour shift system, the wishes of the workers have been taken into consideration?

     Dr Wong Kwei Cheong: Mr Speaker, Sir, the answer is yes.

     Mr Goh Chee Wee (Boon Lay): May I ask the Hon. Minister of State, first, under this 12-hour shift system, will the workers work the same total number of hours? Secondly, presuming that the workers are rostered to work, say, from 7 o'clock in the evening to the next morning at 7 o'clock, in other words they have to work through the night too, how will this really overcome the workers' reluctance to work on the late night shift when this new system requires them to work an even longer late night shift?

     Dr Wong Kwei Cheong: Mr Speaker, Sir, in answer to the first part of the question, as long as the average number of hours worked over a period of three weeks for shift workers is not more than 44 hours per week, then employers and employees can have agreements whereby such work can be carried out.

    As regards the second part of the question, Sir, workers working on a 12-hour

Column: 108

shift will be having more off-days, and this will help them to save transport costs and the additional off-days will be an incentive for them to go and work the 12-hour shift even though they may have to work in the night shift.

MEDISAVE SCHEME
(Details)


    8. Mr Goh Chee Wee asked the Minister for Health (a) if he can furnish details of the proposed Medisave Scheme; and (b) whether the proposed Scheme will affect the medical benefits schemes currently being offered by employers and whether it will not discourage employers from providing medical benefits to employees which are normally covered by collective agreements between the employers and the unions.

     The Minister of Defence and Second Minister for Health (Mr Goh Chok Tong): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Medisave Scheme affects every Singaporean. I will, therefore, discuss the Scheme with various civic organizations and other relevant bodies before finalizing it. As it is, three talks with 150 CCC members are planned for next month.

    I will, therefore, not be able to furnish full details of the Scheme today. I will, however, outline my Ministry's thinking on the subject. At present, the combined CPF contributions from an employer and his employee amount to 45% of the worker's salary. This rate is expected to be raised to 50% within the next three or four years. A portion, equivalent to 6% of the salary, will be reserved to form a Medisave Account. The Medisave Account is an individual savings account to meet hospitalization expenses; it belongs to- the particular employee. It is not an insurance account. The contribution is, therefore, not an insurance premium.

    As the combined contributions to CPF are subject to a ceiling which, at present, equals to $1,350 per month, the 6% contribution to Medisave will also be subject to a ceiling at $180 per month. The employer and the employee will contribute equally, i.e. 3% each.

    Should the employee be hospitalized and incur a hospital bill, he may withdraw

Column: 109

from his Medisave Account to pay for the bill. The Medisave Account also extends to his immediate family members (spouse, parents and children). In other words, he can also withdraw from his Medisave Account to help pay the hospital bill incurred by any of his immediate family members.

    In deriving at this contribution rate of 6%, my Ministry took into account:-

    6. Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam asked the Minister for National Development why his Ministry had served summonses under the State Lands Encroachments Act on occupiers of properties in the Kaki Bukit estate before they were allocated alternative accommodation.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: I must point out that when State lands or acquired lands are to be developed, the Resettlement Department has to follow prescribed legal requirements and procedures to clear the land. The Honourable Member for Kaki Bukit has previously raised this matter with my Ministry. He has been told the reasons for this legal process and he has reassured the affected residents in his constituency that the Government's intention is not to inconvenience them or to evict the eligible residents before alternative accommodation is available.

    However, for the benefit of the Member for Anson, who appears ignorant of the legal requirements, I shall now describe the various steps in the clearance process.

    Notices to Remove or Notices to Quit are first issued against squatters on the land. These are formal notices to the squatters that they have to vacate the site. Upon expiry of the notices, legal action has to be instituted under the State Lands Encroachments Act for the issuance of summonses. However, the squatters need not attend court in person to answer the charge of unlawful occupation of State land if they plead guilty by means of a standard written statement supplied by the Resettlement Department which provides assistance and advice to the squatters to complete this legal process unless they wish to contest the charges in court. Invariably more than 90% of the squatters follow this procedure and are therefore not inconvenienced. In the case of Kaki Bukit, 98% of the squatters accepted this procedure. The purpose of the legal proceedings is to enable the Resettlement Department to obtain Warrants of Dispossession to enforce removal of the squatters from the State lands, if it is necessary subsequently especially in cases where irresponsible persons, including politicians, incite squatters to resist clearance.

    Simultaneously, parallel action is taken to offer alternative accommodation to squatters according to their eligibility and the availability of such accommodation. I must stress that alternative accommodation is an ex-gratia benefit and may be offered to squatters at any point during the legal clearance process. Accordingly, some summonses may have been served prior to the offer of alternative accommodation to the squatters. While the service of notices and summonses constitutes part of the legal clearance process, the Warrants of Dispossession made by the court against the squatters are not enforced until the Resettlement Department has offered alternative accommodation to those squatters who are eligible.

    The clearance of Kaki Bukit follows the normal procedure adopted for the clearance of all other State lands. They are treated no differently from all other squatters facing clearance action elsewhere.
